As I have said a couple of times here, I am selling my company. I have a VERY interested and motivated buyer. He is having trouble with the cash portion of the sale. Current offer is a substantial cash payment, I walk with all the companies on hand cash, 15% of pre tax net for 10 years, and I keep IP and IP support personnel.
 
 Personally, I do not want IP or the support personel, but it is a profitable segment of the business and he is offering it as a way to decrease total sales price.
 
 My idea (counter offer) is:
 
 Same cash being offered now, but I only walk with 80% of the companies onhand cash
 
 15% of pre-tax net over 10 years with a fixed minimum (he has already agreed to a fixed minimum = my current salary)
 
 He keeps IP and support personel, but I recieve 50% of pre tax net for 10 yrs, with a fixed minimum (IP has fixed income currently based on royalties)
 
 I keep auxilary warehouse and old production facility (we just moved to a bigger facility).
 
 
 
 I think he is going to be agreeable to this plan. My question is the structure of payments as far as legacy payments go (IP and percentage of pre tax net). The primary sticking point before was from his bank, which was hesitant to make him the loan he needed due to the fact that on hand cash would essentially be at zero. By leaving 20% of the companies cash intact, he gets his loan, I still pull substantial equity out of the company in the form of cash (plus legacy payments and RE). Then I can go fishing.
 
 I guess what I am looking for is just any thoughts that anybody might have. I recognise that I am taking some risk by allowing future payments to be based on net, but I havce seen this guy in action and I think the risks are acceptable, especially in light of the fact that we are currently carrying a half dozen long term contracts in the aerospace industry (military) that ensure that my 15% will always equal at least my yearly salary, even worst case. 
 
 Overall I calculate that with the legacy payments, I should make about 15% more on the sale with this arrangement, despite the lower up front cash.
 
 Anyway, any thought?

 Get everything you can as close to up front as you can. You may have seen him in action, but the future, especially 10-years, is an unknown, uncontrollable risk. His health could fail in in a few years, accident, economy, etc. If you do a value calculation even using bond rates for the discount factor, you'll take a beating on the salary over that period of that time. I suggest leaving the 20% cash and restructuring the legacy portion as a note equal to your salary for 10-years to be serviced at by minimum 25% of annual pre-tax operating income before extraordinary expenses (the debt service will lower his tax exposure). Three years is normal, five at the outside. For potential excess over the annual salary, use separate notes including audit rights structured to (1) pay the difference between your salary and 15% of net and (2) 50% of IT operating net as a separate agreement for a ten-year period. Include a pre-payment trigger based on prior three year numbers in the event he spins either company off as off-shore IT, related engineering and production become more and more attractive. 
 
 1. The bank will be happy with his cash position. Since your debt will be serviced from operating margin, it won't affect their loan ratios, which is what they live by and upping your take of net margin by 10% isn't a deal breaker. You get more cash (the salary portion) quicker, important with the inflation we're going to face because there's going to be transaction money to be made with very little effort.
 2. He can keep the other agreements off-balance sheet and it won't affect loan ratios or revolving credit facilities. 
 
 Have your numbers person do a NPV on it structured that way and I think you'll both like it.

Inflation is coming, there can be no mistake. the only question is are we looking at massive inflation, or hyper inflation. Current strategy involves massive liquidity (cash sitting in an offshor bank account at 12%, in a mixed basket of currencies to protect against a weakening dollar as well as maximise return).  I see a real problem currently in the US, one that we do not have financial models or past experience to really guide us through. Besides the de-industrialization of the US, we have the dollar falling off a cliff, which is leading to higher poil prices, which is leading to increased trade deficits, which is leading to a weaker dollar, which leads to higher oil prices, which leads to increased deficits, which leads to a weaker dollar........ you see the problem I am sure. There is a good article at http://moneycentral.msn.com/content/P100650.asp by Jim Jubak about such a cycle.

 I use the KISS formula. With the exception of some commercial real estate with long-term, government guaranteed leases, some development LLCs and a mistake, I'm liquid and short-term. I use bonds rather than money market accounts simply because yields are currently higher with almost identical accessibility. I do keep two money market accounts, one to feed our household accounts and the other to feed business accounts, all on zero balance basis. Bond redemption feeding the money market accounts as required while they feed the checking accounts and putting it in at the top. Secured construction cash flow financing is still my favorite short-term investment. One to six-month exposure, three average, with yields of 10-15%. That's hands-on stuff, but I like it because I can see economic changes coming from a long distance. I've also been fortunate in that our last residence and this one are located in very high-growth areas that attract primarily retirees and others with a few bucks and that will continue with increases when baby boomers cash it out. 
 
 I left equity markets well before the dot.com crash (even a blind man could see that coming). I even paid early withdrawal tax penalties to get out of 401k participations from my days of employment, but did make one mistake by participating in a large, rollover LLC development fund about that time. The return is good, but I'm stuck in it until 1-2007 because of the 10% withdrawal rule. I don't see it going south, but would prefer to be totally liquid. Short term investing is much less taxing and, in this day and age, provides me with a better comfort level than anticipating returns from publicized economic growth that doesn't exist. I did learn my lesson and never go in on anything where I'm not at or near the top of the withdrawal list. And IMO cash, liquidity, is now king. Nothing else matters.
